Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Indo-US Workshop on Synthetic and Systems Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program, will bring together 30 accomplished researchers from US and India to identify important problems in the area of systems and synthetic biology of relevance both scientifically and societally, to highlight educational requirements and best practices, and to identify bi-national collaboration opportunities that leverage the scientific expertise available in both nations.

The workshop will be held November 9-12, 2014 on the campus of Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi, India. Approximately 30 senior researchers who are experts in the fields of systems and synthetic biology from the US and India will be in attendance along with representatives from US and India funding agencies. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will also be included. The outcomes of the workshop will be a roadmap for future US-India collaboration in this research area as well as a possible Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) proposal. Research associated with a SAVI in systems and synthetic biology would build research infrastructure, create new educational opportunities, and potentially contribute to the bioeconomy in both nations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Support was provided for a joint Indo-US Workshop on Synthetic and Systems Biology held November 9-12, 2014 in New Delhi, India.  It was co-sponsored by the Department of Biotechnology (DBT), Ministry of Science and Technology, Government of India, and hosted at Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India. The symposium was attended by 24 academic and industrial investigators, representaives of DBT, NSF and USDA and most important, over 60 graduate and undergradiate students from different institutions in India. Though still an emerging field, engineering (synthetic) biology has tremendous potential to harness the power of biology to solve pressing real-world problems for humanity and the planet, such as transmutation of energy-rich molecules into carbon neutral fuels and industrial chemicals; the design of precisely targeted, personalized medicines; remediation of environments polluted by fertilizers, industrial waste, or chemical or biological warfare agents; the assurance of food supplies to meet an explosively growing global population. With the field rapidly progressing and other binational collaborations well underway, the a joint Indo-US partnership was critical to the development of the engineering (synthetic) biology field in India and to foster collaborations between institutions in the two countries, enabling mutual scientific progress, joint discussions of emerging ethical questions, development of best practices for intellectual property, and, importantly, the exchange of scholars and students between US and India.
